tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"This is for the director of music to use in worship"

tn.ref: A psalm of the sons of Korah
tn.text: "This is a psalm that the sons of Korah wrote"
Clapping your hands is associated with celebration. AT: "Clap your hands in celebration" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: shout to God with the sound of triumph
tn.text: "shout to God with joyful voices." Here the word "triumph" refers to the joy associated with victory.

tn.ref: He subdues peoples under us and nations under our feet
tn.text: These two phrases are parallel and mean that God enabled Israel to conquer their enemies. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
to conquer and place under the authority of another
The writer speaks of conquering other nations as if it were putting those nations underneath their feet. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: He chooses our inheritance for us
tn.text: The writer speaks of the land of Israel as if it were an inheritance that God has given the people as a permanent possession. AT: "He chooses this land as an inheritance for us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

Here the word "glory" refers to a source of pride and represents the land that God has given to his people as an inheritance. AT: "the land in which Jacob takes pride" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The word "Jacob" refers to the nation of Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: God has gone up with a shout
tn.text: The writer speaks of God's conquering the nations as if God were a king ascending his throne, which was located in the temple. AT: "God has gone up into the temple as people shouted" (UDB) or "God has ascended to his throne as people shouted" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: Yahweh with the sound of a trumpet
tn.text: This phrase parallels the previous phrase. The verb may be supplied for clarity. AT: "Yahweh has gone up as people blew trumpets" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: Sing praises to God, sing praises; sing praises to our King, sing praises
tn.text: The phrase "sing praises" is repeated for emphasis. You may omit the repetition if it is awkward in your language. AT: "Sing, sing praises to God; sing, sing praises to our King" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Possible meanings are that the rulers of the nations 1) "gather in front of the people" (UDB) or 2) "gathered together with the people" so that all may worship God as king.

tn.ref: the shields of the earth belong to God
tn.text: Possible meanings are that "shields" 1) refers to instruments of war. AT: "God has more power than the weapons of all the kings on the earth" (UDB) or 2) refers to the rulers of the nations who are spoken of as shields who protect their nations. AT: "the kings of the earth are subject to God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
